title: Expression and purification of untagged asynuclein

authors.name: Alain Ndayisaba
authors.affiliation: Khurana Lab, Harvard Medical School, Brigham and Women's Hosptial

source.description:
Thaw
-
of BL21(DE3) competent E. coli
for ~
or until melted.

source.body: If more than of cells are to be thawed, the remaining aliquot can be frozen using a 100% ethanol and dry ice bath.

source.description:
Once the cells are completely thawed, add
-
of
-
of pET21a-alpha-synuclein and gently mix by inverting the tube.

source.body: Our lab has had consistent success using ~50-ng of pET21a-alpha-synuclein DNA for transformation.

source.description:
Following the addition of the plasmid, incubate the cell and plasmid mixture
for about
.

source.body: This time can be reduced to a minimum of , but the transformation efficiency significantly decreases with each halving of the time.

source.description:
Then, heat-shock the cell and plasmid mixture for exactly
in a
water bath.

Remove the mixture from the water bath and place it
for
, then add
-
of SOC medium to the tube.

source.body: SOC medium is ideal, however LB medium can also be used but will result in a roughly two fold loss of transformation efficiency.

source.description:
Incubate the bacteria at
for
, while shaking at ~
. After incubation, repeatedly invert the tube to mix the culture well and then plate
onto selection plates. Incubate the plate(s) upside-down overnight at
.

source.body:
Note: When first plating the transformants, is it recommended that different volumes of the culture (e.g. , , ) are plated to ensure that at least 5-6 single colonies grow on each plate, but not so many that picking one becomes challenging.
Note: If the plasmid contains resistance for ampicillin, the outgrowth step is not necessary[6]. However, if different resistance genes are present in the expression vector, it is necessary to perform this step to allow for cell recovery and expression of the antibiotic resistance gene(s).

source.description:
On the following day, choose a single colony to inoculate in ~
of LB medium at

(pre-culture).

The next day, add a 1:20 dilution of the pre-culture to LB medium and grow at
until OD600 = 0.5-0.6. Once an OD600 = 0.5-0.6 is reached, induce the expression of αS with
IPTG and let the culture grow at
for ~
.

source.body: The amount of IPTG to be used for the induction (typically - ) depends on the cells, construct and culture conditions. It is recommended to perform a quick optimization, when setting up the expression protocol, in order to determine the optimal amount of IPTG. Also, it is not necessary to grow the cells at a lower temperature (e.g. - ) because overexpressed αS does not tend to form inclusion bodies in E. coli due to its high solubility in the bacterial[17].

source.description:
Then, spin the culture at
for
(
). After the spin, remove the supernatant and freeze the pellet
at
. Freezing the pellet in this fashion already lyses most of the bacteria.

Cell Lysis:

1. Pre-heat a hot plate and a
Erlenmeyer Flask to the minimum temperature to initiate boiling. While the hotplate and flask are reaching the right temperature (enough to bring the culture to a boil but not too high that it will cause charring), submerge the frozen pellet in IEX Buffer A (
TRIS,
NaCl,
EDTA,
) and vortex until the pellet is completely resuspended, taking extra care not to leave any pellet in solution.

source.body: This protocol is written for an ÄKTAprime plus FPLC system equipped with a UV and conductivity detectors. Although other FPLC systems will largely follow the same protocol, it is advised to always refer to the manufacturer’s specifications.
If cells are spun in a centrifuge tube, approximately of IEX buffer A should be enough to fully submerge the pellet.

source.description:
2. Pour the resuspended cell suspension into the pre-heated
Erlenmeyer flask. Increase the hotplate temperature and let the mixture rise to an even boil.

3. After the first visible signs of boiling, allow the mixture to boil for an additional
to denature and precipitate proteases and other protein contaminants.

4. After boiling, let the lysate cool down to
, transfer it to
centrifuge bottles and spin it at
for
(
). Filtrate the supernatant through a
or
filter. Bring the supernatant up to approximately
with IEX buffer A.

source.body: It is highly recommended to incubate the lysate mixture at after cooling on the benchtop to avoid damaging centrifuge tubes upon high-speed centrifugation.

source.description:
Ion Exchange Chromatography (IEX):

1. Wash the FPLC system with IEX Buffer A at
.

2. Connect the columns (2x
HiTrap Q HP columns) in the presence of a flow rate of
to ensure that no air enters the column. After the columns are attached, equilibrate them with IEX Buffer A at
for
or until the conductivity reaches a steady measurement for ~
.

source.body: If columns are stored in 20% ethanol it is recommended to wash the columns with MilliQ before equilibrating the column with buffer. This will ensure that salts will not precipitate in the column.

source.description:
3. Following equilibration, load the cell lysate mixture onto the columns
at a max flow rate of
.

4. Wash the column with IEX Buffer A until a steady (around
) plateau in the 280-nm absorbance is achieved, in order to remove any weakly bound contaminants.

source.body: The wash step can also be performed using low percentages of IEX buffer B (e.g. 5-10%), in order to have more stringent wash conditions. However, this can also wash off small amounts of αS and should thus be tested by checking the waste of the washing step by Coomassie-stained SDS-PAGE or WB. In total, the volume of IEX Buffer A used during the wash step should be between - .

source.description:
5. After the UV absorbance plateaus, elute the protein with a gradient, from 0% to 100%, of IEX Buffer B (
TRIS,
NaCl,
EDTA,
) over
and collect fractions every
.

6. Analyze all the fractions and the flow-through (the unbound lysate fraction which passes through the column and is collected in the FPLC waste during the lysate loading step) via Coomassie-stained SDS-PAGE or Western Blot (αS usually elutes between 25 and 35 mS) to determine the fractions with the highest concentration of αS.

source.body: For a lab-scale expression (typically 1- or 2-L expression), 2x 5 mL HiTrap columns should be enough to allow for complete aS binding. If a larger expression is required, it is recommended to increase the number of HiTrap columns in the system or switch to a column(s) with a larger bed volume(s). Always analyze the flow-through fraction to ensure complete binding of aS to the columns. If aS is detected in the flow-through fraction, increase the number of columns in the system to increase the overall binding capacity.

source.description:
7. Pool the fractions (usually around a conductivity of ~25 mSi when adopting this protocol and purification system) containing the greatest amount of αS and (eventually) concentrate down to
, which will then be loaded on a size-exclusion column.

4. At the beginning of the run, switch the valve position to “Inject”. At this point, the pooled IEX fractions will be injected onto the SEC column. After
of
ammonium acetate are run through the loop, switch the valve position back to “Load”.

Size-Exclusion Chromatography (SEC):

1. Wash the FPLC system with
ammonium acetate,
(
.). Attach the SEC column (HiPrep 26/60 Sephacryl S-200 HR) in the presence of a buffer flow rate of
., to ensure that no air enters the column.
3. Inject the pooled IEX fractions in the loop, making sure not to inject air bubbles into the system or column. The valve position must be set to “Load” when injecting the sample onto the loop.

source.body: Injecting small amounts of air into the columns is unavoidable (especially when working with a sample loop). Air bubbles, when eluting, will give off characteristic spikes in the UV absorbance trace[20]. On the other hand, if large amounts of air are injected onto the column (i.e. resin discoloration from the presence of air is visible in the bed), generously flush the system and column with buffer. This applies to both IEX columns and SEC columns, but SEC columns are much more sensitive to the presence of air in their resin because of their resin packing being critical for resolution (and cracks or lacunae can disrupt it completely and require column re-packing).

source.description:
2. Attach a
loop to the six-way valve of the FPLC system and flush it with
of
ammonium acetate to remove any aggregated protein or built-up waste.

5. Flush a total of
of Ammonium Acetate buffer through the FPLC, collecting 14x
fractions between
and
corresponding to a molecular weight of 60 kDa.

8. After lyophilization, seal the tubes with Parafilm, to prevent moisture from entering, and store at
for short-term storage (1-2 weeks) or
for long-term storage.

7. Aliquot the pooled fractions into
aliquots, then flash-freeze them using liquid nitrogen or a dry ice/ethanol bath and lyophilize (or store frozen at
) the samples.

6. Analyze the fraction purity via Coomassie-stained SDS-PAGE and pool 5-6 of the purest fractions. Measure the absorbance of these fractions at 280 nm (ε(aS)=0.412 mL·mg-1·cm-1). Usually purity of >95% can be obtained.

description: This protocol details the generation of untagged a-synuclein.
